G.L. c. 208, \u00a728.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, to modify the existing custody order entered on March 15, 2021, issued by this Court, on the grounds of material and substantial changes in circumstances affecting the best interests of the minor children, Emily Johnson (age 10) and Lucas Johnson (age 8).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a720.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, to modify the existing custody order entered on March 15, 2021, issued by this Court, on the grounds of material and substantial changes in circumstances affecting the best interests of the minor children, Emily Johnson (age 10) and Lucas Johnson (age 8).

Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Jessica Thompson, and respectfully petitions this Honorable Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, to modify the existing custody order entered on March 15, 2021, issued by this Court, on the grounds of material and substantial changes in circumstances affecting the best interests of the minor children, Emily Johnson (age 10) and Lucas Johnson (age 8).

Mass. G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a73\u20136.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §28, G.L. c. 209C, §20, and Mass. G.L. c. 215, §§3–6, which authorize the Probate and Family Court to modify custody and visitation orders where a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification serves the best interests of the children.

Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 65.proposition: Issue temporary orders as necessary pursuant to Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 65 to ensure the immediate protection of the minor children pending final hearing;

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: See Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006) (holding that a court may modify custody when new conditions affect the child’s welfare).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/joint-physical-custody case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, and addresses the standard for permitting relocation and applying a best-interests test when parents share joint physical custody. It does not address when or under what circumstances a court may modify custody based on new conditions, nor does it articulate a rule that a court may modify custody when new conditions affect the child’s welfare. The focus is on whether removal should be authorized, not on modification of custody per se as framed in the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “After some time, and a four-day trial, a different judge weighed the best interests of the children and determined that removal to New Hampshire in the manner requested by the mother was not in the best interests of the children and thus would not be authorized by the court. … The judge … did not award sole physical custody to either party, deciding instead to order continued shared legal and physical custody.”

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: See Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015) (material changes in parental fitness and home stability support modification).
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion is a divorce and custody decision, not a post‑judgment modification case. The court discusses initial custody, visitation suspension, and a removal order, but it does not analyze or apply the standard for modifying an existing custody or visitation order based on material changes in parental fitness or home stability. The only mention of future modification is a brief acknowledgment that the father’s rights were not terminated and he could potentially seek modification, which does not establish any rule that material changes in fitness and home stability support modification.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “Despite the judge’s decision documenting the father’s abuse of the mother and concluding that the father’s visitation with the child should be suspended, the judge did not terminate the father’s parental rights, and clearly left open the possibility of a modification of his order precluding visitation. In a case such as this, the father’s constitutional rights as a parent require that the judge considering a request for removal take into account the potential for the father to seek a resumption of visitation.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: See Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001) (children’s exposure to violence constitutes material change warranting modification).
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss children’s exposure to violence at all, nor does it identify such exposure as a material and substantial change warranting modification of custody. Instead, the case holds that a relocation request and a temporary, court-imposed change in custody did not constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification, and ultimately reinstates custody with the mother and allows removal. Using this case to support the proposition that exposure to violence is a material change is inaccurate.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements which, on all of the uncontested evidence, had been in place with no ill effect on the child since the parties’ separation in October, 1995.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) (best interests of child is paramount in custody determinations).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court explicitly frames the governing standard for both custody and removal decisions in terms of the child’s best interests and reiterates that this is the “paramount” concern. In discussing the removal statute, the opinion states that “upon cause shown” means removal must be in the best interests of the child, and emphasizes that although the custodial parent’s welfare is important, the child’s best interests always remain paramount. This directly supports the cited proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that … the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined… Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent…’”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) (court may alter custody to protect child’s well-being).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for making custody determinations in the context of domestic violence and requires probate judges to make explicit findings about the impact of abuse when awarding or continuing custody. However, it does not state or develop a general principle that a court may alter custody to protect a child’s well‑being; that authority flows from statutes and general custody law, not from any articulated holding here. The case is about the adequacy of findings, not about changing custody as a protective measure, so it only indirectly, not directly, supports the cited proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.… Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings….”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003) (best interests include safety, emotional security, and stability).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard at length and emphasizes that stability and continuity of placement are themselves important components of a child’s best interests. While the opinion does not list ‘safety, emotional security, and stability’ as an explicit three-part formula, its reasoning clearly treats stability and the child’s welfare (which encompasses safety and emotional well‑being) as central elements of the best-interests analysis. Thus, it is a reasonably accurate authority for the idea that best interests include stability and related protective concerns, though the exact phrasing is not used.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.raw_text: Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 914 (1993)
Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.proposition: See Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 914 (1993) (exposure to domestic violence may render custody arrangement inconsistent with child’s welfare).
Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.support_reasoning: The opinion as provided focuses on parental unfitness, instability, homelessness, substance abuse, and the child’s preference for adoption. It does not discuss domestic violence or analyze how exposure to domestic violence affects custody or the child’s welfare. Therefore, citing this case for the specific proposition that exposure to domestic violence may render a custody arrangement inconsistent with a child’s welfare is not accurate.
Adoption of Arthur, 34 Mass. App. Ct. 91.relevant_excerpt:
The record supports the judge’s conclusion that the mother has consistently been incapable of providing a stable and safe household for her son. Further, the judge specifically found that since 1987, the “[m]other’s actions . . . have not been consistent with her expressed wishes to regain custody of [Arthur]. She has been inconsistent in her visits and . . . continues to show no ability to place her son’s needs before her own.”

The father’s plight is even worse. The judge noted in his findings, and the record supports his view, that over the years the father has been homeless...

Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 284 (1985).proposition: See Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 284 (1985) (modification requires showing of changed circumstances that affect child’s best interests).
Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 284 (1985).case_name: Spring v. Geriatric Authority of Holyoke
Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 284 (1985).support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 284 (1985), but Spring v. Geriatric Authority of Holyoke, 394 Mass. 274 (1985), a tort and statutory liability case about privacy and government immunity. It does not concern domestic relations or standards for modification of child-related orders, and nowhere discusses a requirement of changed circumstances affecting a child’s best interests. Therefore, this case cannot support the proposition about modification standards in family law.
Hale v. Hale, 394 Mass. 284 (1985).relevant_excerpt: The opinion deals with claims including invasion of privacy, emotional distress, G.L. c. 66A, G.L. c. 93A, breach of contract, and governmental immunity. It does not address modification of custody, support, or any child-related orders, nor does it articulate a standard requiring a showing of changed circumstances affecting a child’s best interests.

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: See Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976) (court may adjust visitation conditions to ensure protection and stability for children).
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion affirms a custody decree that entirely denies the mother visitation based on the child’s welfare, and notes that custody orders may be modified in the future. It does not discuss or exemplify a court’s active adjustment of visitation conditions to ensure protection and stability; instead, it upholds a no-visitation order. The suggestion of possible future modification is brief and statutory, not an articulated principle about tailoring visitation conditions for protection and stability.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “The material facts found and reported by the judge support his action in awarding custody of the child to the father and stepmother with no rights of visitation by the mother… We hold that the judge correctly applied these principles in deciding this case and that on the facts found and reported by him he did not abuse his discretion. As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30…”
